paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses various TTR gene mutations associated with transthyretin familial amyloid polyneuropathy (TTR-FAP) and provides details on penetrance data.

individual_records.evidence_sentence: All patients presented with sensorimotor polyneuropathy, and 17 (94.4%) of them developed autonomic neuropathy.

The exclusion criteria of HCs were as follows: (1) skin numbness or paresthesia; (2) muscle atrophy or weakness; (3) other disorders of the peripheral nervous system; and (4) chronic diseases of other organs.

The exclusion criteria of HCs were as follows: (1) skin numbness or paresthesia; (2) muscle atrophy or weakness; (3) other disorders of the peripheral nervous system; and (4) chronic diseases of other organs.

functional_data.summary: The study indicates that TTR mutations lead to autonomic dysfunction and sensorimotor polyneuropathy.

variants.segregation_data: The variants segregate with disease in families as indicated by the familial nature of TTR-FAP.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the high penetrance of TTR mutations in the affected population.
key_quotes: Different TTR mutations were identified by gene testing, including Val30Leu mutation in 3 patients, Gly83Arg, Lys35Asn, Val30Met, Glu61Lys, and Ala97Ser mutation in 2 patients, respectively, and Val30Ala, Glu42Gly, Ala36Pro, Phe33Val and Asp38Val mutation in 1 patient, respectively.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text.
